INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY OPERATIVE REPORT

DATE OF PROCEDURE: April 10, 2025 CC Referred Physician: Dr. Miller

INDICATION FOR OPERATION
[REDACTED] is a 45-year-old male who presents with bronchial stricture. This patient is a patient with history of prolonged intubation with stricture that required increased complexity, specifically 4 balloon dilations and 5 applications of cryotherapy. This resulted in >50% increased work due to time, technical difficulty, and physical/mental effort required.

CONSENT
The nature, purpose, risks, benefits and alternatives to Bronchoscopy were discussed with the patient in detail. The patient wished to proceed and informed consent was obtained.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
J98.09 Other diseases of bronchus, not elsewhere classified

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
J98.09 Other diseases of bronchus, not elsewhere classified

PROCEDURE
31645 Therapeutic aspiration initial episode
31622 Dx bronchoscope/cell washing
31624 Dx bronchoscope/lavage (BAL)
31630 Balloon dilation
31641 Destruction of tumor OR relief of stenosis by any method other than excision (eg. laser therapy, cryotherapy)
22 Substantially greater work than normal (increased intensity, time, technical difficulty)

ATTENDING
Dr. P. Pulmonologist

ASSISTANT
PA Smith

SUPPORT STAFF RN: [Name] RT: [Name]

ANESTHESIA
General Anesthesia

MONITORING
Pulse oximetry, heart rate, telemetry, and BP were continuously monitored by an independent trained observer that was present throughout the entire procedure.

INSTRUMENTATION
Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope; 1.7mm Cryoprobe; 6/7/8 Elation balloon.

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS
Minimum

COMPLICATIONS
None

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL
After the successful induction of anesthesia, a timeout was performed (confirming the patient's name, procedure type, and procedure location).

Patient Position: Supine

Initial Airway Inspection: The laryngeal mask airway is in good position. The vocal cords appear normal. The subglottic space is normal. The trachea is of normal caliber. The carina is sharp. The tracheobronchial tree was examined to at least the first subsegmental level.

Airway Exam:
Stenosis: Notable for stricture of the RUL (80% patent). Diameter was 4 mm.

Secretions: Copious mucoid secretions bilaterally, thick plug at RUL

Therapeutic Aspiration & Lavage: Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clean out the Trachea (Distal 1/3), Right Mainstem, Bronchus Intermedius, Left Mainstem, and RUL Carina from mucus and mucus plug.

Endobronchial Stenosis Treatment: Endobronchial obstruction at RUL was treated with the following modalities:

Cryotherapy: Using a 1.7mm probe, ablation was performed with 45-second freeze-thaw cycles for a total of 5 applications.

Balloon Dilation: Performed at RUL using a 6/7/8 Elation balloon to dilate to 8 mm. Total 4 inflations with dilation time of 60 seconds each were performed during this specific sequence.

Results: Prior to treatment, affected airway was noted to be 80% patent. After treatment, the airway was 95% patent.

Conclusion: The patient tolerated the procedure well. There were no immediate complications. At the conclusion of the operation, the patient was successfully extubated in the operating room and transported to the recovery room in stable condition.

SPECIMENS
BAL - RUL

IMPRESSION / PLAN
45-year-old male treated for bronchial stricture.
Successful restoration of RUL patency from 80% to 95% using balloon dilation and cryotherapy.
Follow-up results.
Follow-up CXR.
Repeat bronchoscopy on [Date].

INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY OPERATIVE REPORT

DATE OF PROCEDURE: January 12, 2025 CC Referred Physician: Dr. Ingraham

INDICATION FOR OPERATION
[REDACTED] is a 77-year-old female who presents with bronchial scarring. This patient is a granulomatosis with polyangiitis patient with scarring that required increased complexity, specifically 4 balloon dilations and 8 applications of cryotherapy. This resulted in >50% increased work due to time, technical difficulty, and physical/mental effort required.

CONSENT
The nature, purpose, risks, benefits and alternatives to Bronchoscopy were discussed with the patient in detail. The patient wished to proceed and informed consent was obtained.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
J98.09 Other diseases of bronchus, not elsewhere classified

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
J98.09 Other diseases of bronchus, not elsewhere classified

PROCEDURE
31645 Therapeutic aspiration initial episode
31622 Dx bronchoscope/cell washing
31624 Dx bronchoscope/lavage (BAL)
31630 Balloon dilation
31641 Destruction of tumor OR relief of stenosis by any method other than excision (eg. laser therapy, cryotherapy)
22 Substantially greater work than normal (increased intensity, time, technical difficulty)

ATTENDING
Dr. P. Pulmonologist

ASSISTANT
PA Smith

SUPPORT STAFF RN: [Name] RT: [Name]

ANESTHESIA
General Anesthesia

MONITORING
Pulse oximetry, heart rate, telemetry, and BP were continuously monitored by an independent trained observer that was present throughout the entire procedure.

INSTRUMENTATION
Flexible Therapeutic Bronchoscope; 1.9mm Cryoprobe; 8/9/10 CRE balloon.

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS
Minimum

COMPLICATIONS
None

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL
After the successful induction of anesthesia, a timeout was performed (confirming the patient's name, procedure type, and procedure location).

Patient Position: Supine

Initial Airway Inspection: The laryngeal mask airway is in good position. The vocal cords appear normal. The subglottic space is normal. The trachea is of normal caliber. The carina is sharp. The tracheobronchial tree was examined to at least the first subsegmental level.

Airway Exam:
Stenosis: Notable for scarring of the LLL (50% patent). Diameter was 3-4 mm.

Secretions: Copious mucoid secretions bilaterally, thick plug at LLL

Therapeutic Aspiration & Lavage: Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clean out the Trachea (Distal 1/3), Right Mainstem, Bronchus Intermedius, Left Mainstem, and LLL Carina from mucus and mucus plug.

Endobronchial Stenosis Treatment: Endobronchial obstruction at LLL was treated with the following modalities:

Cryotherapy: Using a 1.9mm probe, ablation was performed with 60-second freeze-thaw cycles for a total of 8 applications.

Balloon Dilation: Performed at LLL using a 8/9/10 CRE balloon to dilate to 12 mm. Total 4 inflations with dilation time of 45 seconds each were performed during this specific sequence.

Results: Prior to treatment, affected airway was noted to be 50% patent. After treatment, the airway was 95% patent.

Conclusion: The patient tolerated the procedure well. There were no immediate complications. At the conclusion of the operation, the patient was successfully extubated in the operating room and transported to the recovery room in stable condition.

SPECIMENS
BAL - LLL

IMPRESSION / PLAN
77-year-old female treated for bronchial scarring.
Successful restoration of LLL patency from 50% to 95% using balloon dilation and cryotherapy.
Follow-up results.
Follow-up CXR.
Repeat bronchoscopy on [Date].
